question: If Earth rotates once per day and one year has 365 days, how many rotations does Earth complete during one revolution around the Sun?

content.source_1: Earth completes one revolution around the Sun (a tropical year) in about 365.2422 mean solar days.
content.source_2: The cycle of day and night is caused by Earth’s rotation about its axis.
content.source_3: A mean solar day—the interval from one noon to the next—is about 24 hours and is what we count as one “day.”
content.source_4: Earth’s sidereal rotation period (one 360° spin relative to distant stars) is about 23 hours 56 minutes (86,164 seconds), a few minutes shorter than a mean solar day.
content.source_5: Because Earth advances along its orbit as it rotates, each solar day is roughly 4 minutes longer than one axial rotation; over one full orbit, the number of axial rotations is about one more than the number of solar days.
